prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
WIBTA if I make my gf start paying some of the bills over a single incident?
Gf and I live together.   She only works part time.    I pay all the rent and bill.  I never minded it until last night. 

We went to grab some take out and I realized I left my wallet in my work pants.  I told her she’d have to get it.   Her attitude about the whole thing was so ugly.   At first she couldn’t believe it and asked me if I was serious in this almost disgusted tone.  She acted so put out by it. 

It was some fucking take out.  Under $40.  I pay EVERYTHING.  I understand she only makes a little, but that little is probably a lot with no expenses.   I know it was only one incident, but I haven’t been able to get it out of my head since.   It’s really rubbing my the wrong way.  She wouldn’t be able to pay a lot of the bills, but I feel like it’s time for her to start carrying her weight.  Just out of principal.  
"""

I think the author is not in the wrong, but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user wants to know if the person who wrote the question is in the wrong. The situation is about a girlfriend who works part-time and the author, who pays all the bills, wants her to start contributing after a single incident where she got upset about paying for takeout.

First, I need to consider the dynamics here. The author is paying all the bills, which is a big deal. The girlfriend works part-time, which might mean she has a lower income. The incident in question was about a $40 takeout where the author made her pay. His reaction is that her attitude was "ugly" and "disgusted," which he found upsetting. Now he's considering making her start paying some bills, even though he acknowledges she can't cover much.

Is the author in the wrong? Well, making someone start paying bills because of one incident might be a bit harsh. Financial responsibilities in a relationship often depend on mutual agreement and circumstances. The author has been handling all the expenses, which the girlfriend might not have expected to change suddenly after an isolated event. The key here is whether the request is fair given the context.

The author's reasoning is based on principle, wanting her to contribute. But if she's only making a little and hasn't been contributing before, expecting her to take on more after one incident could be unfair. Also, the way the author is framing it—focusing on her reaction to paying a small amount—might indicate he's overreacting. Maybe he's feeling taken advantage of, but it's important to communicate and agree on financial responsibilities rather than changing things abruptly.

On the other hand, it's reasonable for both partners to contribute to shared expenses. However, the approach here seems to be punitive, stemming from his frustration over the takeout incident. That might not be the healthiest way to handle it. The answer likely hinges on whether the author is addressing a legitimate need for shared responsibility or lashing out because of hurt feelings over the takeout.

In relationships, communication is key. If the author feels it's time for her to contribute more, that's a valid point, but doing it because of a single incident might not be fair. The girlfriend might not have realized the expectation was for her to help with expenses, especially if the author has always covered everything. So, while the author's intention might be to share the financial load, the method—using a minor incident as a catalyst—could be seen as unfair. Therefore, the author might be in the wrong for making a big change based on a single event without prior discussion.
